bestBHT.bht: God's message to Peter through the vision was clear and powerful: He had made all nations equal, abolishing the ceremonial distinctions between Jews and Gentiles. Peter was not to profane what God had cleansed, for in God’s eyes, there is no longer any impurity. The vision taught Peter and all believers that the old laws and customs that separated Gentiles from God’s chosen people were no longer relevant. It was a divine declaration, and as disciples, it was vital to follow God’s judgment.

Henry Alford: God letting down from heaven clean and unclean alike, Jew and Gentile,—represented that He had made of one blood all nations to dwell on the face of all the earth

God having purified these, signified that the distinction was now abolished which was ‘added because of transgressions’ (Gal. iii. 19),—and all regarded in his eyes as pure for the sake of His dear Son.
They reveal what was needed for the occasion, in a figure: God letting down from heaven clean and unclean alike, Jew and Gentile
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: What God hath cleansed, that call not thou common."
The ceremonial distinctions are at an end.
Gentiles, ceremonially separated from the chosen people, and debarred from that access to God in the visible ordinances of His Church which they enjoyed, are now on a perfect equality with them.
Albert Barnes: What God hath cleansed - What God has pronounced or declared pure. If God has commanded you to do a thing, it is not impure or wrong.
It was to show him that they who had been esteemed by the Jews as unclean or profane - the entire Gentile world - might now be admitted to similar privileges with the Jews.

When the distinction was abolished; when other nations were to be admitted to the same privileges, the laws which were made to keep up such a difference received their death-blow, and expired of course.
Marvin Vincent: Do not profane it by regarding and calling it common.
John Calvin: It is not for us to allow or condemn any thing; but as we stand and fall by the judgment of God alone, so is he judge of all things."

Seeing they eat such meats as are most fit, both for delicacy and also for riot, why do they abstain from eating bacon, as from some great offense, save only because they imagine that that is unclean and polluted which is forbidden by the law of their idol?"

We must always ask the mouth of the Lord, that we may thereby be assured what we may lawfully do; forasmuch as it was not lawful even for Peter to make that profane which was lawful by the Word of God.
Philip Schaff: What God hath cleansed, that call not thou common."
It is incumbent on us to observe that there is a distinct reference here to a Divine ordinance.
The Lord Jesus did actually, by this discourse of His, make all things pure.
Archibald T. Robertson: Make not thou common what God cleansed.
Do thou stop making common what God cleansed.
Peter had just called 'common' what God had invited him to slay and eat.
John Gill: What God hath cleansed; that is, hath pronounced clean and lawful to be used.
No man, not any Gentile, Barbarian, Scythian, or be he who he would, was common or unclean, and his company to be avoided as such.
Distinctions both of men and meats were now to be laid aside.
John Wesley: What God hath purified — Hath made and declared clean.
Nothing but what is clean can come down from heaven.
St. Peter well remembered this saying in the council at Jerusalem, Acts 15:9.

bhtAttempts.bht: God’s message to Peter through the vision was clear and powerful: He had made all nations equal, abolishing the ceremonial distinctions between Jews and Gentiles. Peter was not to profane what God had cleansed, for in God’s eyes, there is no longer any impurity. The vision taught Peter, and by extension all believers, that the old laws and customs that separated Gentiles from God’s chosen people were no longer relevant. They were invited to share in the same privileges and access to God that the Jews had. It was a divine declaration, and as disciples, it was vital for them to recognize and follow God’s judgment.

God’s message to Peter was clear: He had made of one blood all nations, abolishing the ceremonial distinctions between them. The vision symbolized that in God's eyes, all are pure through His dear Son. The old distinctions were at an end, and Gentiles were now on equal footing with the chosen people. It was a divine ordinance, and Peter was to stop regarding and calling what God had cleansed as common or unclean. The message was crucial for all believers to comprehend and follow God's judgment.

In Acts 10:15, God's vision to Peter showed that He had made all nations equal and abolished the ceremonial distinctions between them. The distinctions, added because of transgressions, were no longer relevant in God's eyes. Gentiles were now on perfect equality with the chosen people, and nothing God pronounced clean should be considered common. It was a clear sign that the old laws were no longer binding, and believers were to obey God's judgment and recognize the purity He had declared.
